author: sky.cactus
content:
I have been thinking of the claim that some people have made that boils down to:
> Mining farms are very efficient, but they are not very elastic.  Home miners, are not efficient, but they are very elastic.
If we believe this to be true, would it increase "decentralization" (e.g., move more mining toward home miners and away from farm miners) if the reward randomly changed on a seasonal level?

author: maxvoltage.
content: This is the reason why I am looking to migrate to Nvidia GPUs.  That way, I will have have more options instead of the small number of options for AMD.  With that said, I am hopeful that Team Red Miner will expand their mining software to include more algorthms so AMD GPUs will have more options, but I am not banking on that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone with a gaming rig who can't mine profitably will just turn it off when it is unprofitable and turn it on when it is.  They have near zero CapEx, because their resources are purchased for *other* reasons and they are just opportunistically mining when it is profitable.

author: sky.cactus
content: A farm miner on the other hand usually has reasonably high CapEx that they amortize over some period of time.  Turning their rigs off has a reasonable chance of ending the life of the rig as well (due to skimping on certain costs that a gaming rig wouldn't skimp on).

author: maxvoltage.
content: <@301186049323958275> interesting thought...  Not sure what you mean by seasonal?  Are you referring to when the China mining farms go off line due to the lack of hydro power?  I don't think that is what you mean but that is where my mind goes when you say "seasonal".

author: sky.cactus
content: By having unpredictable mining rewards (e.g., core devs randomly crank it up or down), anytime it is up home devs would join in, and when it was down they would leave.  Mining farms would not be able to rely on any sort of stable income, and thus have less incentive to build out significant infrastructure.
